Raynaud's phenomenon (RP): paroxysmal vascular acrosyndrome with vasoconstriction, triggered by exposure to cold.

Erythermalgia: paroxysmal vascular acrosyndrome with vasodilatation, triggered by heat, exercise or orthostatism.

Acrocyanosis: permanent vascular acrosyndrome with a pronounced cold, cyanotic appearance of the extremities.

Frostbite: trophic acrosyndrome in the toes, more rarely in the fingers.

Digital ischaemia: ischaemia localised to the fingers or toes.

question.title: What is a key characteristic of Raynaud's phenomenon, acrocyanosis, erythermalgia, digital ischaemia, and frostbite?
question.description: These conditions are all types of acrosyndromes, but they differ in their trigger and physiological response.

option_a.title: They are all caused by poor circulation
option_a.description: This is a common misconception about these conditions, but it is not entirely accurate.

option_b.title: They are all characterized by vasoconstriction and vasodilation
option_b.description: This option is partially correct, but it oversimplifies the complex physiological responses of these conditions.

option_c.title: They are all permanent conditions with no cure
option_c.description: This option is incorrect, as some of these conditions can be managed with treatment and lifestyle changes.

option_d.title: They are all triggered by exposure to cold
option_d.description: This option is correct, as Raynaud's phenomenon, acrocyanosis, and frostbite are all triggered by cold exposure.
